posts.name:
Ankur Warikoo
Ankur Warikoo
posts.content:
Imagine you are driving at 50 kmph.

At that speed, the ride may seem boring but it can be enjoyable.

You don't have to brake often.
You don't have to honk often.
You can munch on something.
Have a nice chat with your fellow passenger.

And almost predictably arrive at your destination on time.

Now compare that with driving at 80 kmph.

There is no peace.
You are cutting corners.
Braking often, honking often.
Getting angry at the slow ones in front of you.
You can't enjoy the music nor the company.
You are constantly looking at the road.

And worse, all of this has increased the chances of an accident.

If you reach your destination, you will reach perhaps 2-3 mins earlier than the one at 50 kmph.

This is your career.

The 50 kmph driver represents the person who grows their career steadily.

Taking time to learn.
Build relationships.
They value balance and sustainability.

They don‚Äôt chase shortcuts but still arrive at their goals predictably, safely, and with their peace intact.

The 80 kmph driver is the one chasing rapid success.

Hopping between jobs for titles, taking shortcuts to impress, neglecting health, and burning out in the process.

The journey becomes stressful, and even if they achieve success, it comes at a heavy price.

Yes, there will still be bumps and unexpected stops, even at 50 kmph.
But the ride will be much more enjoyable and far less draining.

No speed is worth it if it takes away your life.

No career path is worth it if it takes away your peace.

comments.commentText: This analogy beautifully captures the essence of a balanced career journey. It's a vital reminder that sustainable growth often leads to a more fulfilling experience, allowing us to savor our successes while maintaining our well-being. Thank you for sharing such insightful perspectives,.

posts.name:
Pejman Milani
Pejman Milani
posts.content:
Don't compare your chapter 1 to someone else's chapter 20.

We see overnight success.
We don't see the sleepless nights.

We see someone standing tall.
We don't see the stumbling it took to get there.

The struggles are temporary tangles on the long thread to success.

Illustration by me

posts.name:
Michael Kainatsky
Michael Kainatsky
posts.content:
Someone gave me a really nice compliment yesterday. 


She said it was admirable that I didn't care what people thought
of me on.

While it's very much appreciated, I must be honest, too.

There is not really all that much to fear when it comes
people's thoughts of me on this platform.

The reason is that there's not many people thinking for
themselves on this platform.

It seems I am safe for the time being.

I will continue to build amazing relationships and the rest. . .

I'll be content with making the AI commenters look silly.

Yours truthfully,

posts.name:
Dan Goodman
Dan Goodman
posts.content:
Rep increases severance 5x to $50k after wrongful termination.

I consulted with an amazing salesperson and person named Briana. She was terminated after 11 months of employment despite being in two protected classes for age and a medical condition.

Briana was recruited with lies and deceit and lured away from a good job she had for 5 years. Walking away from a strong pipeline of deals and a secure role.

She suffered through a sexist and toxic work environment for 11 months. One she stayed in way too long, given the damage it did to her confidence and outlook. Feeling mentally abused and tormented, leaving her a shell of her former self.

Briana was terminated just weeks after providing constructive feedback to the CEO about her manager and process challenges. Just weeks prior to a significant one-year cliff equity vest from happening.

She was gaslit about false claims of performance despite never being put on a PIP or a word of concern about performance.

Briana was blamed for a client issue caused by a VP 4 months earlier and sited as contributing factor for her termination. She was fired for performance despite not one member of the team having closed a single deal other than Briana that quarter.

Briana was third female rep terminated without a PIP in the last 6 months, while 2 male counterparts failed two PIPs each and are still employed. No one on the team ever came close to hitting quota as the comp plan was setup so no one could.

During her short tenure Briana penetrated a new market segment the company had been attempting to enter for years based solely on Briana‚Äôs outbound efforts.

Yet she was always made to feel that she was not as good as her male counterparts which led to her continuously questioning herself.

Typically Briana was offered only 1 month severance worth $10k. Something she would never considering signing away her rights for.

We put together a scathing document proving the discrimination and mistreatment. The employer did not know what hit them. They confirmed receipt and came back with an offer of $25k, 250% more than originally offered.

Briana desperately wanted to take the offer and move on. I convinced her there was a lot more to come and to go at least one more round.

I always like to hear "No" at least once if not twice before giving in and even then, in many instances, we will escalate to the CEO or Board of Directors if necessary.

We turned the heat up on our next response and the employer doubled the offer from the last one, from $25k to $50k. I knew there was more to be had but Briana was done. She was satisfied and accepted the offer.

It was a trying and anxiety filled 10 days writing the document and negotiating a settlement. Briana is extremely proud of herself and feels on top of the world. She has her mojo back.

comments.commentText: It's a great thing that you help people not just win just settlements, but win back their confidence as well.

posts.name:
Heather Monahan
Heather Monahan
posts.content:
There‚Äôs no such thing as ‚Äúeffortless.‚Äù

I lost my job. It wasn‚Äôt pretty.
I rebuilt my life from scratch. It wasn‚Äôt easy.
I became a bestselling author. It took grit.
I stepped on stage as a speaker. It took courage.
I built my confidence. It took showing up every day.

Success isn‚Äôt magic; it‚Äôs work.
Every ‚Äúeffortless‚Äù win has a grind behind it.
Every confident leader has battled self-doubt.

Don‚Äôt fall for the myth.
Put in the work. Push through the setbacks.
You‚Äôll earn the life you deserve‚Äîand it‚Äôll be worth it. 

Do you believe in effortless??

comments.commentText: Regardless of the situation, you have to put in the work!

posts.name:
Garima Jain
Garima Jain
posts.content:
This made me quit LinkedIn for real.

A real time story:
I planned to organize an audio event on LinkedIn which is my fav thing to do lol.

But unfortunately, I found out that LinkedIn discontinued audio events (Heartbreak) 

Then, I planned to organize a LinkedIn Live but that also did not work because of some glitches.

I was receiving messages on when I'll be live but I was helpless.

And then I ended up doing an event on Google meet.

It was not a good day but definitely my best event.

Undeniably, LinkedIn did this to simplify its events creation process and to focus more on video content.

I wanted to quit LinkedIn?
-- Not really lol


Let's explore more of these LinkedIn new updates and experiment them ‚≠ê

posts.name:
Jatin Tiwari
Jatin Tiwari
posts.content:
SAP Notes Ô∏è

SAP Notes is a set of instructions to remove known errors from SAP systems. Using the Note Assistant tool, SAP Notes can be applied to the system.

You can access the Note Assistant tool using transaction SNOTE.

Release notes describe the new functions and changes in each SAP release. Using the Help menu, you can display release notes for any SAP application and release. Ô∏è

You can also search for release notes using keywords and attributes.

Whenever you receive a new SAP release, you should review the release notes. The release notes describe new functions that may affect the task you perform in the system. Ô∏è

They also describe how to change customizing and installation parameters before upgrading from one SAP release to another.

ProcedureÔ∏è

You can display release notes in the SAP Library or from within the SAP System.
To display release notes in the SAP system, proceed as follows:

From the menu, choose Help > Release notes.

The Find Release Notes screen appears.

For a list of all release notes, choose Complete list 3.0/3.1 or Complete list from 4.0.

Highlight the release notes for the SAP version you want to see and choose Choose.

A hierarchical list of the available release notes appears, with plus signs to the left of every item that has sublists.

Display one of the release note sublists by double-clicking it.Ô∏è

The sublist appears, containing release notes, more sublists, or both. You can identify a set of release notes by the fact that no plus or minus sign appears to the left of it.

Repeat step 3 until you see the desired release notes.

Double-click the release notes you want to display.Ô∏è

The release notes appear. To print the selected release notes, choose Print.
Searching for Release Notes
You can search for release notes by keyword or by attribute.

A keyword is a term associated with a release note, such as "Purchasing" for release notes in purchasing.Ô∏è

An attribute refers to the type of information the release note contains. You can narrow the search for release notes by choosing the attributes of the release notes you want to display.

For example, a release note has the attribute Changes to Customizing parameters if the new function requires a change in your system‚Äôs Customizing parameters. Ô∏è

Thus, if you want to display all release notes requiring a change to Customizing, you can list all release notes with this attribute.

To search for release notes: Ô∏è

From the menu bar, choose Help -> Release notes.

To search by keyword, choose full-text search. Ô∏è

To search for release notes that contain only a certain type of information, choose Attribute search.

Enter your search criteria (keywords or attributes).

Choose Find. Ô∏è

The system displays any release notes that match your search criteria.Ô∏è

If you found this useful, followfor more insights from the top 1% every week.

My SAP Community

comments.commentText: Very helpful Guide for the newbie to understand SAP Note Application !
